facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1958 was a taluqdar owning several taluqdari villages in Dholka Taluka of Ahmedabad District.

anchor.surface_text: The material facts in Civil Appeal No. 254 of 1958 may be briefly stated The appellant was a taluqdar owning several taluqdari villages situate in the Dholka Taluka of Ahmedabad District.

facts.text: In 1922-23, there was a revision settlement of land revenue for lands in Dholka Taluka including taluqdari villages, fixing aggregate land revenue at Rs. 62,627-2-6.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1922-23 there was a revision settlement of land revenue of the lands situate in the said taluka including the said taluqdari villages. Under that settlement the aggregate of the land revenue payable

facts.text: In 1925-26, Government of Bombay under s.22 of Gujarat Taluqdars Act, 1888 declared jama of Rs. 32,643-3-0 payable for taluqdari villages, to remain in force for 30 years.

facts.text: Bombay Taluqdari Abolition Act, 1949 passed and came into force on or about August 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1949, the Bombay Legislature passed the Bombay Taluqdari Abolition Act, 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Abolition Act, and it came into force on or about August 15, 1950.

facts.text: By s.3 of Abolition Act, taluqdari tenure abolished and incidents extinguished; appellant became occupant of the lands.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 3 of the Abolition Act, taluqdari tenure was abolished and all the incidents of the said tenure attaching to any land comprised in the taluqdari estate were extinguished. Under the Abolition Act, the

facts.text: After expiry of 30-year period in 1955-56, talatis called upon appellant to pay full land revenue assessment.

anchor.surface_text: After the expiry of the thirty year period, the talatis of the respective villages called upon the appellant to pay the full land revenue assessment in respect of the lands comprised in the said villages.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Bombay High Court for writ of prohibition against realising enhanced land revenue for 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contending that he was only liable to pay jama declared to be payable by him by the Government in 1925-26 filed a Writ Petition in the High Court of Bombay for the aforesaid relief.

22.  1  If a taluqdars estate, or any portion thereof, is  wholly or partially exempt from landrevenue and its liability to payment of land-revenue is  subject to special  conditions or restrictions, the jama payable to Government in respect of such estate or person thereof shall, if a survey-settlement has been extended thereto, be the aggregate of the surveyassessments of the lands  posing such estate or such portion thereof, minus such deduction, if any, as Government shall in each case direct. The Governor in Council may declare the amount of jama so ascertained fixed for any term  exceeding thirty years.

issues.text: Whether the appellants are liable to pay only the jama declared under section 22 of the Taluqdars Act after the expiry of the thirty-year period or the full land revenue assessment fixed in the settlement registers, having regard to the relevant provisions of the Taluqdars Act, the Abolition Act and the Code

anchor.surface_text: The question is which of the two contentions should prevail having regard to the relevant provisions of the Taluqdars Act, the Abolition Act and the Code. It will be convenient to read the relevant provisions from the two Acts.

issues.text: Whether the declaration made by the Governor in Council under section 22 of the Taluqdars Act fixing the amount of jama is a 'settlement of land revenue' within the meaning of section 117R of the Code so as to continue in force until the introduction of a revision settlement

anchor.surface_text: If the declaration of the Governor in Council is a settlement of land revenue within the meaning of this section, it would continue to be in force till the intro- duction of the revision settlement. It is, therefore, necessary to ascertain the meaning of the words settlement of land revenue in the section.

arguments.claim: The jama ascertained and declared under s.22 Taluqdars Act was fixed at the revenue settlement and by s.117R Bombay Land Revenue Code continues till re-settlement, so appellants liable only for that jama, not enhanced revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned Counsel for the appellants, contends that the jama ascertained and declared to be due from the appellants for a period of thirty years was fixed at the revenue settlement, that by reason of s. 117R of the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879 (hereinafter referred to as the Code), they were liable to pay only the said assessment till there was re-settlement and that therefore the respondents have no right to make a demand for an amount higher than that declared to be due from them in 1925-26.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at settlement would certainly be a settlement of land revenue within the meaning of s. 117R of the Code and that would companytinue to be in force til

arguments.court_reasoning: Jama declaration is not a 'settlement of land revenue' under s.117R as it is aggregate minus deduction, distinct from survey settlement operations under Ch.VIII-A; expires after fixed term per s.22(2).

arguments.claim: Under Taluqdars Act, essential distinction between revenue settlement and ascertainment/declaration of jama; post-Abolition Act, jama payable only till 30-year expiry, thereafter occupants liable for full land revenue assessment per settlement registers.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor General counters this argument by contending that under the Taluqdars Act, there was an essential distinction between revenue settlement and the ascertainment and declaration of the jama that after the Abolition Act, the amount of jama was payable only till the expiry of the thirty year period and that thereafter the appellants who bad become mere occupants would be liable to pay the entire land revenue assessment already fixed in respect of those lands.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: at settlement would certainly be a settlement of land revenue within the meaning of s. 117R of the Code and that would companytinue to be in force til

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; declaration under s.22 fixed for term not exceeding 30 years, saved by Abolition Act s.5(2)(b) and s.17 only so long as in force; post-expiry, liable per Code as occupants.

arguments.claim: Taluqdars Act provides for special revenue administration: survey/settlement under Code (ss.4-5), separate jama fixation under s.22 as aggregate survey assessments minus deduction, fixed for term <=30 years.

anchor.surface_text: The position emerging from the aforesaid provisions may be summarized thus The Taluqdars Act was enacted to make special provision for the revenue administration of the estates held by certain superior land-holders in the districts of Ahmedabad, Kaira, Broach and the Panch Mahals. Section 4 enabled the Governor in Council to direct a revenue survey or revised revenue survey of any taluqdari estate under the provisions of the Bombay Land Revenue Code.

arguments.claim: Post-Abolition Act, taluqdars become occupants liable for land revenue per Code; s.5(2)(b) saves jama right under s.22/23 Taluqdars Act only so long as declaration/settlement remains in force.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 5 of the Abolition Act, the taluqdars became occupants within the meaning of the Code, i.e., they were deemed to be holders in actual possession of unalienated lands other than the tenants with the result that all the taluqdari lands became liable to, the payment of land revenue in accordance with the provisions of the Code and the rules made thereunder. Sub-section 2 of s. 5 saved the right of any person to pay jama only under an agreement or settlement recognized under s. 23 or a declaration made under s. 22 of the Taluqdars Act so long as such agreement, settlement or declaration remained in force.

arguments.claim: s.117R Code deems prior 'settlements of land revenue' continue till revision settlement; defined per s.117C as result of operations under Ch.VIII-A (grouping lands, standard rates, etc.).

anchor.surface_text: Section 117R of the Code reads All settlements of land revenue heretofore made and introduced and in force at the date of the commencement of the Bombay Land Revenue Code Amendment Act, 1939, shall be deemed to have been made and introduced in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter and shall, notwithstanding anything contained in section 117E, be deemed to continue to remain in force until the introduction of a revision settlement. Settlement is defined by s. 117C (1) to mean the result. of the operations conducted in a zone in order to determine the land revenue assessment.

arguments.claim: Jama declaration under s.22 or agreement/settlement under s.23 Taluqdars Act is not a 'settlement of land revenue' under s.117R Code; it is aggregate minus deduction, not result of Ch.VIII-A operations per survey number.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration- under s. 22 or the agreement or settlement of jama mentioned in s. 23 (1) might be described broadly as a settlement entered into between the Government and a taluqdar but it was not a settlement of land-revenue within the meaning of S. 117R of the Code, for settlement of revenue was the result of operations carried on in respect of different classes of lands in the manner prescribed by Ch. VIII. A of the Code or the settlement in respect of such lands in accordance with the pre-existing laws it was beyond the scope of Ch. VIII-A to ascertain the jama, though the rates fixed under such a settlement were taken as the basis by the Government in ascertaining the jama payable by the taluqdar.

arguments.qualifiers: broadly as a settlement (but not under s.117R)

arguments.claim: Abolition Act s.17 repeals Taluqdars Act but saves declarations under s.22; combined with s.5(2)(b), jama protected only till expiry of fixed term (1955-56 here); thereafter full liability per settlement registers.

anchor.surface_text: The jama payable by the taluqdar was distinct from the revenue assessment of the land comprised in the taluqdari estate and they could not be equated. Section 17 of the Abolition Act repealed the Taluqdars Act and expressly provided that the repeal of the said enactment shall not affect any declaration made or any agreement or settlement recognized in respect of the taluqdari estates. Section 5 (2) (b) of the Abolition Act expressly saved the agreement or settlement recognized under s. 23 or a declaration made under s. 22 from the operation of the Act till such agreement, settlement or declaration remained in force. ... We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.

holdings.text: the declaration under s. 22 or the agreement or settlement of jama mentioned in s. 23 (1) might be described broadly as a settlement entered into between the Government and a taluqdar but it was not a settlement of land-revenue within the meaning of S. 117R of the Code, for settlement of revenue was the result of operations carried on in respect of different classes of lands in the manner prescribed by Ch. VIII. A of the Code or the settlement in respect of such lands in accordance with the pre-existing laws it was beyond the scope of Ch. VIII-A to ascertain the jama, though the rates fixed under such a settlement were taken as the basis by the Government in ascertaining the jama payable by the taluqdar.

anchor.surface_text: The declaration- under s. 22 or the agreement or settlement of jama mentioned in s. 23 1  might be described broadly as a settlement entered into between the Government and a taluqdar but it was not a settlement of land-revenue within the meaning of S. 117R of the Code, for settlement of revenue was the result of operations carried on in respect of different classes of lands in the manner prescribed by Ch. VIII. A of the Code or the settlement in respect of such lands in accordance with the pre-existing laws it was beyond the scope of Ch. VIII-A to ascertain the jama, though the rates fixed under such a settlement were taken as the basis by the Government in ascertaining the jama payable by the taluqdar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jama declaration is aggregate of survey assessments minus deduction, not result of Ch.VIII-A operations grouping lands by classes and fixing per survey number assessments; beyond scope of chapter to fix jama.

holdings.text: The jama payable by the taluqdar was distinct from the revenue assessment of the land comprised in the taluqdari estate and they could not be equated.

anchor.surface_text: The jama payable by the taluqdar was distinct from the revenue assessment of the land comprised in the taluqdari estate and they could not be equated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Taluqdars Act, survey settlement fixes per survey-number assessment; s.22 separately ascertains jama as aggregate minus deduction for fixed term.

holdings.text: Section 5 (2) (b) of the Abolition Act expressly saved the agreement or settlement recognized under s. 23 or a declaration made under s. 22 from the operation of the Act till such agreement, settlement or declaration remained in force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 of the Abolition Act repealed the Taluqdars Act and expressly provided that the repeal of the said enactment shall not affect any declaration made or any agreement or settlement recognized in respect of the taluqdari estates. Section 5 (2) (b) of the Abolition Act expressly saved the agreement or settlement recognized under s. 23 or a declaration made under s. 22 from the operation of the Act till such agreement, settlement or declaration remained in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abolition Act s.5 makes taluqdars occupants liable per Code; s.5(2)(b) and s.17 save jama rights only while declaration or agreement 'remains in force'; repeals Taluqdars Act but preserves prior declarations temporarily.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Declaration fixed for 30-year term under s.22(2); not saved beyond expiry by s.117R as not a land revenue settlement; post-expiry, as occupants under Abolition Act s.5, liable for full assessment per prior survey settlement registers.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.

outcome.relief_summary: Jama declaration under Taluqdars Act expired in 1955-56; appellants liable to pay full land revenue per settlement registers from 1955-56; no writ or prohibition granted

anchor.surface_text: The declaration- under s. 22 or the agreement or settlement of jama mentioned in s. 23 1  might be described broadly as a settlement entered into between the Government and a taluqdar but it was not a settlement of land-revenue within the meaning of S. 117R of the Code, for settlement of revenue was the result of operations carried on in respect of different classes of lands in the manner prescribed by Ch. VIII. A of the Code or the settlement in respect of such lands in accordance with the pre-existing laws it was beyond the scope of Ch. VIII-A to ascertain the jama, though the rates fixed under such a settlement were taken as the basis by the Government in ascertaining the jama payable by the taluqdar.

We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.

We, therefore, hold that the declaration made by the Governor in Council in 1925-26 expired in 1955-56 and the appellants became liable to pay the entire land-revenue according to the settlement registers from the year 1955-56.
